<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 262, 170, 278]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 285, 393, 301]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[747, 285, 861, 300]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[722, 310, 861, 325]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 338, 376, 353]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 365, 343, 380]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 397, 218, 412]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 413, 769, 533]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 560, 208, 574]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 575, 693, 606]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 68, 91, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 876, 101]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the heating of a solid metal cylinder. Fig. 1.1 shows the cylinder of cross-sectional area \(A\) and height \(h\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 107, 667, 273]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 286, 507, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 316, 876, 364]]<|/det|>
The student places the cylinder and an electrical heater in a beaker of water. The electrical heater is switched on and the student measures the time \(t\) for the temperature of the water to increase by \(\Delta \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 375, 865, 393]]<|/det|>
A number of cylinders of the same material but with different cross-sectional areas are available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 405, 539, 422]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(t\) and \(A\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 433, 552, 451]]<|/det|>
\[P t = A h W \Delta \theta + Z \Delta \theta\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 463, 606, 481]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) is the power of the heater and \(W\) and \(Z\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 494, 677, 510]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(t\) and \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 507, 682, 524]]<|/det|>
Explain how your results could be used to determine values for \(W\) and \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 536, 776, 554]]<|/det|>
You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 551, 536, 567]]<|/det|>
In your account you should pay particular attention to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 581, 376, 598]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 610, 390, 626]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 638, 331, 654]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 666, 336, 682]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 694, 425, 710]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 91, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 764, 87]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the current in a circuit containing a cell, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 88, 665, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 254, 507, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 282, 875, 317]]<|/det|>
The student connects two resistors of resistances \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\) between P and Q. The ammeter measures the current \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 327, 715, 345]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the experiment with different resistors between P and Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 356, 581, 375]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(I, R_1\) and \(R_2\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 384, 546, 405]]<|/det|>
\[E = I(R_{1} + R_{2} + r)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 414, 767, 433]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the electromotive force (e.m.f.) and \(r\) is the internal resistance of the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 444, 139, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 443, 682, 465]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{I}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \((R_1 + R_2)\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 473, 583, 492]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 653, 875, 672]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 683, 875, 701]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 698, 876, 715]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 141, 87]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 68, 504, 87]]<|/det|> Values of \(R_{1}, R_{2}\) and \(I\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 97, 625, 116]]<|/det|> Each resistance value has a percentage uncertainty of \(\pm 5\%\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 127, 514, 144]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 156, 878, 431]]<|/det|>
\(R_{1}/\Omega\)\(R_{2}/\Omega\)\((R_{1}+R_{2})/\Omega\)\(I/\text{mA}\)\(\frac{1}{I}/\text{A}^{-1}\)
223317.2
224714.2
225612.8
334712.4
335611.4
475610.1
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 451, 680, 479]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \((R_{1} + R_{2}) / \Omega\) and \(\frac{1}{I} /\mathrm{A}^{-1}\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 485, 515, 504]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \((R_{1} + R_{2})\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 486, 876, 504]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 515, 136, 534]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 510, 175, 533]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 510, 526, 536]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{I} /\mathrm{A}^{-1}\) against \((R_{1} + R_{2}) / \Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 545, 435, 564]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \((R_{1} + R_{2})\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 546, 876, 564]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 574, 171, 593]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 574, 876, 606]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Both lines should be clearly labelled. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 591, 876, 609]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 618, 171, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 618, 876, 650]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 842, 876, 861]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 68, 175, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 67, 875, 100]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 214, 876, 232]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 244, 141, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 244, 176, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 243, 876, 276]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine values of \(E\) and \(r\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 435, 875, 453]]<|/det|>
\[E = ............................................................\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[529, 465, 875, 483]]<|/det|>
\[r = ............................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 481, 876, 498]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 509, 175, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 509, 502, 527]]<|/det|>
Determine the absolute uncertainty in \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 642, 876, 660]]<|/det|>
<form>absolute uncertainty in \(E =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 673, 141, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 672, 876, 705]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated using the same cell. The value of \(R_{1}\) is \(22\Omega\). Determine the resistance \(R_{2}\) that would give a current of \(7.5 \text{mA}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 803, 876, 822]]<|/det|>
\[R_{2} = .................................................... \Omega \quad [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[792, 834, 876, 852]]<|/det|>
